toa3k7u3bdVAAw-1NtJ24w.text: Tried mostly small plates. Great location. Reasonably priced.   +  Shrimp wrapped/fried Veggie samosas Soup of the day (lentil, ok but a bit bland)  -  Tempura mushrooms Tom Yum veggie (asked for medium, still unbelievably spicy) Pancake with veggies (too sweet for me)

2ykC9DIRe3X0ngD7ru6_Cw.text: In a city that lives on tourism, this is the worst kind of a place that can be. Late afternoon, we thought of popping by for some tea and snacks and were seated. After a wait of about 15 minutes, the server came over to take the order, even though there were barely two tables with other customers. We placed the order of chai and pakoras. The server kept hurrying us up to place the main course order and when we told him we were not ordering main course, his attitude changed entirely. He curtly told us we will not be served anything if we don't order main course, so we either order main course or leave. It was shocking beyond belief!  First, nowhere on the menu or entrance did they say they had this weird policy of forcing customers to main course. Second, the attitude of this server was rude to say the least. He treated us as if we were beggars. I only wish we had gotten his name. Go here only if you wish to be insulted.

TL1VC6TRSbh5EUZictirFg.text: Shamoli was a quick - and late - dinner for us. Having just arrived in Edinburgh and checked into out hotel down the street, it was well after 2100 when we walked in with our two kids.  One of three tables being occupied, service was efficient albeit not the most warm and friendly in the world, and the food hit the spot. We opted for the Indian half of the menu and we're pleased with out choices.  All told, out of there in about 45 minutes .. mission accomplished!

gPnVP6mkyQdjfZUquzSwQg.text: My friends and I came here for lunch and enjoyed it tremendously. The place serves both Indian and Thai food. The buffet lunch was only 8 and was awesome! Typical Indian dishes available - pakora, curries, etc. Can't speak for the Thai food since I didn't try much of it, but definitely go for the Indian food!

photos.caption: Photo of Shamoli Thai & Indian Cuisine - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Buffet
Photo of Shamoli Thai & Indian Cuisine - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Shamoli Thai & Indian Cuisine - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

hRIWnlj7zAMdIM4OlXHZBw.text: I love that they offer Indian and Thai. We ordered dishes from both menus and were impressed with both. The only reason why they aren't getting 5 stars is because the servers are not particularly friendly and they seated everyone at tables right next to each other, even though the place was not full.

M_DxM06smhoX2bK6PZKXlA.text: One of the worst places I have been to eat in Edinburgh. We stopped in while walking around exploring the city. As we were being taken to our table a man got up table near the back and came over to stand by our table and started to talk on the phone. I mentioned to the waiter it was hard to hear him over the guy, but the waiter just said ok. So I ordered water to drink then got a duck curry dish 12 and the waiter asked what kind of rice I wanted I asked for plain rice. My Girlfriend asked for curry with a side of naan bread 12+ 4.50 the waiter told her that the naan bread wasn't for curry, she said she understood, she wanted it as a extra side and really didn't want any rice. The waiter seemed very upset and frowned for a minute and said sure with a shrug.  We should left then but it was a long day and we were hungry.   My duck was like jerky, hard to chew and her curry was beyond hot. I love hot food and it was a bit for me. We decided to just go and asked for the check. We were asked how things were and we said not very good and started to explain, but the owner just nodded and gave us our bill.   Water  3.50 And rice 4   Was a little shocked as I haven't spent any money on water since 1980's

J8yaY4UV-byk46r9xfK-yQ.text: I chase green curry across the globe! Maybe the best green curry I have ever eaten.  The sweet potatoes are almost desert!  My wife had pad Thai and it was out of this world.  Don't forget to kick things off with Tom Yum soup is the best I have EVER had.  Most Tom Yum are bland to mediocre, not this! It was delicately balanced while spicy all at the same time.  They made it with Lime leaves and served it with a slice of lemon.  I could have eaten a a bowl instead of a cup! If you are tired of Scottish food and need a change, this is the place.  Absolute 10 of 10

xD_LDVB4NeXfASLfiu733w.text: Quick lunch spot if you want buffet or ordering off menu.  I ordered off menu. Tom Kha soup with chicken was Excellent. Had Lamb Korma for main dish.  Lamb was tough- like steak- but had good flavor.  Would recommend Korma but would absolutely come back here just for the soup.

mutxfi5J99s3PZIzJ1ceBw.text: Off the Mile and up some stairs, this rather pleasant room hides away from the busy streets behind old arched casements.  When Moray L suggested we come here for a catch-up dinner, I looked it up here on Yelp and was a little apprehensive based on the other reviews. But hey, what's life if you don't take a risk now and then?  Well, I'm kind of glad we did. The place itself is rather spacious and very comfortable, with low lighting (they bring up the lights a little brighter over an occupied table, which is quite snazzy) - altogether quite pleasing, especially on a cold, rainy December night. One touch that really doesn't work, though, is a large digital clock with red numbers - even counting the seconds - which "chimes" the hour every 30 minutes. It's a little disruptive, not to mention slightly apocalyptic.  Now then, when it comes to curries, I love chicken korma. I mean I really love it. I don't choose it because I can't handle spice (I can) or because I don't like the unfamiliar (I do) but just because I really, really love it. But normally, I feel cowed, worried that I will be judged as a pleb, so I order something else instead. Of course, I always enjoy my food; I don't order to spite myself. However, sometimes I just long for that creamy rich korma... Well, this was the day! Defiantly, I decided to navigate with determination to the korma, through an impressively extensive menu - the second half of the menu is Indian; the first half, it claims, is Thai - I'm no expert in Thai so can't comment on the remarks in previous reviews that it lacks authenticity. Moray L was certainly looking forward to her meal at least, having eaten there before, and promising me that the sweet potato fritters were "the best thing ever!"  The sauces that arrived with our poppodums were a little lacklustre and I think they might have come out of bottles, but they were fine. Our waiter, on the other hand, did not seem fine. I don't know whether he'd just had some terrible news, or was just having a really bad day, but he walked everywhere at half speed like he'd rather be anywhere else and never cracked a smile once. It wasn't busy in there (about three or four tables including us), but it seemed to take forever to get anything done and after our first drinks he didn't come back to offer us more at any point.  Moray was right, by the way: those fritters really are quite something. As I said, I can't vouch for their Thai authenticity but I don't really care. I just want to eat them all. My korma, too, was lovely - perhaps there wasn't as much as I might have hoped for, but maybe I've been spoiled in the past. It was just fine - not the best I've had, but not disappointing either, and hit the spot nicely. I'd ordered lemon rice to go with it, and it was super-lemony (hooray!), which gave a nice kick to the creaminess of the korma.  Our bill came to just under 40 and, well, here's a useful thing - if you're going Dutch, they handily present the total per person (as divided equally) beneath the main total. Assuming you've ordered roughly the same amount, this means no more faffing around working it out!  It feels like more than three stars, it really does, but just doesn't quite warrant four. But anyway, despite the Clock Of Doom (perhaps explaining the Waiter Of Misery) I'd come back here again happily for a nice cosy meal on a winter's evening.

rd2DFV0xqvoe0JG15LvzAg.text: This restaurant saved us in Edinburgh. After three days of Scottish restaurants (great in moderation, but way too fried for my taste) my friend and I were longing for something spicy or with a bit of vegetables.  The food was delicious - just what we needed (we had the aloo gobi and saag paneer - both very tasty - plus some naan and samosas) and the ambience was relaxing. Great for a night out with a friend or date, and a perfect respite from some of the pub-fare kind of places along this popular touristy street.  I'll be back.

93yCeDT4gWRH4n5ufdsddQ.text: I didn't have a great meal.  Fish cakes were chewy and tough.  The pad thai was like no other I've ever had.  Clearly a low bar given their great location.

CezwXd5vVAwFJeeGxpxhlA.text: This place is wonderful. Imagine getting to eat as much indian food as you can possibly imagine for under a tenner, and even better, on my favourite street in the world, the royal mile. The food is great, the staff are lovely, the location is epic. Say no more.

BzFsM0TeImDfx5Z9usnIag.text: Was walking up the Royal Mile and saw their sign for Thai and Indian buffet. Who could resist?  I'm used to buffets in the US which are rows upon rows of food.  This buffet featured maybe eight chaffing dishes. Decent food. Way too many fried selections for my taste.  The chicken tikka masala was sweet which surprised me. Beyond that, I can't say that anything struck me as particularly great or bad.  A decent meal, especially if you're looking for something other than British food.

hsCQi25Hf31Ea8bg-B53Jg.text: The buffet was very decent and reasonably priced compared to other place. Only con was that the food was not spicy. I would give it a 3.5.

BGcF6S_NSs0yVV-nQEJx1w.text: What made my trip to this place memorable was the waiter knocking over a candle (they moved in for the plates when I was still on my last bite) splashing candle wax in my hair, face and over my clothes. The waiter said sorry sheepishly then erwalked away. That was it. I wasn't angry but I took it upon myself to speak to the manager who casually shrugged and said 'take your clothes to a dry cleaner'I suggested that since I wasn't to blame, perhaps he should pay for the cleaning bill or give us the meal for free (worth a try) but he was not having any of it. Eventually, he sighed and offered me 10 which I accepted although perhaps I should've negotiated on that Especially when he pulled out a roll of money two inches thick. I only decided to pop in here on a whim and first impressions were very much a reminder of what Indian restaurants used to look like although this also had a south east asian twist too with regards to the menu. The food was not too bad to be fair although it was on the expensive side and my new jumper had to be binned (boo)

photos.caption: Photo of Shamoli Thai & Indian Cuisine - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Shamoli Thai & Indian Cuisine - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

UzNWclFY5UP0BjGwA8bOPg.text: The good: very attractive restaurant in the touristy area.   But...the food was not Indian, what it was I cannot say.  There are no Indian spices being used,I couldn't recognize any of the food.  They brought 'papadum'  and some sauces.  I asked for an order of Indian pickles and chutneys...they told me we already had them and pointed to the sauces on the table...uhhhh, ok, chutney is pretty universal (although some can be very exotic but I digress) and that was not chutney.  Next up- all of the dishes were bland and very sweet like they had been made with canned tomato sauce (or ketchup). I asked for my food very spicy and they said that the food could only be prepared as it was (aka all the food is pre-cooked and they are just reheating it).  So I asked for some hot pickle or hot sauce.  They brought some ketchupy looking stuff and warned me that it was very hot....it tasted like ketchup with a half drop of Tabasco in it.  Granted I am used to amazing Indian food in Los Angeles where you are taking your life into your own hands when you ask for your food spicy as they will take the opportunity to punish you for tempting the Indian spice deities...but...really?  Ketchup?   There were no spices to be found, I don't know how to describe the flavors in the four dishes I tasted other than sweet and bland.   On a good note they were nice to my son and brought him a little dish of ice cream as a bonus.  But they did forget to make his food and he ate naan for dinner. They also forgot to bring me my glass of wine but still put it on the bill along with a charge for an extra order of rice we did not order or get.  When we pointed this out they took it off the bill but the bill returned with a gratuity added...I'm not cheap because I don't want to pay 12 pounds for items I didn't receive and I wouldn't think of not tipping a waiter so I was annoyed by this.  Oh and it also took them nearly 20 minutes to get us the check in the first place even though we had an extremely restless small child and asked them several times to bring the check.

oBPCDHvOCpW71a75IOTMgg.text: after a long walk back from a concert late at night and freezing this place appeared. and was amazing.  the service was a little slow but then again it was after 11pm on a tuesday.  we both got pad thai (veggie and prawn) and they were surprisingly good.  neither of us are spicy people so we were very happy with it coming mild and being able to add our spices in.  the garlic nann was hot and fresh but not very garlicy.  other than that no complaints at all.   oh and for a veggie pad thai it was great to see SO many veggies added in instead of them just making it minus the meat.
